titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ireland House Oral History Collection AIA.030
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rebecca Altermatt

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-03-28T15:59-0400

did.abstract: Multi-generational interviews conducted since 2005 as part of an undergraduate oral history course for the Irish Studies program at New York University, under the auspices of Glucksman Ireland House and also by doctoral students and faculty.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Glucksman Ireland House. New York University.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Interviews were conducted by students in the Irish Studies program. Materials are transferred to the Archives after access copies of interviews have been created on DVDs and transcripts typed up. Interviews continue to arrive in the Archives annually.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number;
Archives of Irish American, Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
relatedmaterial.p: Irish Immigration Reform Movement Records AIA 016

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: irisharchives@library.nyu.edu

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with restrictions as noted per individual interview.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into one alphabetical series by interviewee. Dates recorded refer to date of interview.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Multi-generational interviews conducted since 2005 as part of an undergraduate oral history course for the Irish Studies program at New York University, under the auspices of Glucksman Ireland House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Ireland House Oral History Collection consists of multi-generational interviews conducted since 2005 as part of an undergraduate oral history course for the Irish Studies program at New York University, under the auspices of Glucksman Ireland House. Each interview has been transferred to DVD; some interviews are on multiple DVDs. The collection includes summaries of interviews (not transcripts) and supporting biographical and background information on the interviewee. Original tapes of the interviews are housed separately.

controlaccess.subject: Irish Americans
Irish Americans |x Social life and customs.

did.unittitle: Benson, Sean (b. 1960), one of the organizers of the Irish Immigration Reform Movement, former Executive Director of the Emerald Isle Immigration Center and a member of its board.

Burns, Edward Jr. (b. 1968), is a writer, director, and actor who shot to fame in 1995 when his film, The Brothers McMullen, which he wrote, directed, and starred in, about three Irish American brothers coming of age on Long Island.
Cagney, Bridget (b. 1937) retired program analyst for the Institute of International Education and a member of "Point Thank You,‚Äù a post-9/11 support group in New York City.

Campbell, Colm (b. 1935), Executive Director of the New York Irish Center in Long Island City, former Director of the Irish Apostolate USA, and former Director of Youth Services for the Diocese of Down and Connor in Northern Ireland.
Culhane, Noreen M. (b. 1950), an Executive Vice President at the New York Stock Exchange and the 1970 New York Rose of Tralee
D'Arcy, Kathleen Walsh (two interviews, Feb 12 and Apr 22)
Dolan, Joan (b. 1937), former McNiff dancer, founding member of the Bedford (NY) Ceili group, and wife of Irish traditional pianist Felix Dolan.
Dunne, Vincent (b. 1935), a forty-two year veteran of the New York Fire Department who writes and lectures nationally on fire and firefighter safety.
Fallon, John J. (b. 1919) retired Principal of Bay Ridge High School and former president of the American Irish Teachers Association
Flannelly, Adrian (2 inteviews Nov 13 and Nov 19)
Grimes, Claire (two interviews Feb 4 and Feb 11; publisher Irish Echo)
Hartigan, Daniel (two interviews, Mar 29 and Dec 9)
Kelly, Donald A. (b. 1935), retired Senior Vice President of Emigrant Savings Bank and President of the Executive Committee of the Emerald Isle Immigration Center

Kelly, Sr. Theresa (b. 1934), a member of the Sisters of Mercy of the Mid-Atlantic Community who, after a long teaching career, retired as Principal of Our Lady of Refuge in East Flatbush, Brooklyn (NY).
King, Peter T. (b. 1944), Republican Congressman from Long Island and one of the architects of the Northern Ireland peace process in the 1990s.
Laverty, Charles (two interviews Oct 16, 2009 and Feb 19, 2010)
Mahon, Pat (b. 1958), an executive with Bear Stearns and Co., and a 1973 All-Ireland button accordian champion.
McAllister, Brian (b. 1932), president of McAllister Towing & Transport, a tugboat firm operating on the Eastern seaboard but principally in New York harbor.
Murphy, Sr. Regina (b. 1939), the property manager for the Sisters of Charity of New York and an advocate for corporate responsibility, fought hard to establish the McBride Principles.

O'Driscoll, Mae (b. 1939) retired Assistant Vice President of the facilities management department for J.P. Morgan Chase, one of the organizers of the Irish Immigration Reform Movement, and a Trustee and Secretary of the Executive Committee of the Emerald Isle Immigration Center.

Rooney, James E. (b. 1967) director of Firstlink at the Univeristy of Pittsburgh's Institute for Entrepreneurial Excellence, Katz Graduate School of Business, and grandson of Pittsburgh Steelers founder Art Rooney.
Ryan, Fr. Gerald R. (b. 1920), pastor of St. Luke‚Äôs R.C. Church in the South Bronx and the longest serving pastor in the Archdiocese of New York.
Sax, Eithne Golden (b. 1919) retired multilingual translort for the United Nations, daughter of Irish nationalist organizer Peter Golden, and pupil of Irish republican author Ernie O‚ÄôMalley.
Scally, Robert J. (b. 1937), retired Professor of History, New York University and inaugural Director, Glucksman Ireland House, New York University.
Sexton, John E. (b. 1942), President of New York University and former Dean of its School of Law.
Smyth, Treasa Goodwin (radio personality; wife of Tommy Smyth)
Original recordings: for Staff use only
